message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only HIV is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding due to the risk of transmission to the infant. Breastfeeding with active hepatitis B or C or latent tuberculosis may require precautions but is not an absolute contraindication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only HIV is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding due to the risk of transmission of the virus to the baby. Hepatitis B can be prevented with vaccination and hepatitis C and latent tuberculosis can be managed to reduce the risk of transmission to the baby.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only HIV is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding due to the high risk of mother-to-child transmission. Hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through breast milk but can be managed with appropriate precautions. Latent tuberculosis does not pose a risk to the infant during breastfeeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. HIV is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding, as there is a high risk of transmission of the virus to the child through breast milk. Hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through breast milk, but with appropriate treatment and monitoring, breastfeeding may still be an option. Latent tuberculosis does not pose a risk to the child through breast milk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding due to the high risk of transmission to the infant through breast milk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only HIV is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding, as it can be transmitted through breast milk. Hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through breast milk, but with proper precautions, the risk of transmission can be minimized. Latent tuberculosis does not pose a significant risk to the infant.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, HIV is the only infection that is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding. This is because the risk of transmitting the virus to the baby through breast milk is high. Hepatitis B and C may be transmitted through breast milk, but the risk can be minimized with proper treatment and precautions. Latent tuberculosis does not pose a risk for transmission through breast milk.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most common cause of vertical transmission of HIV is through breast milk, making it an absolute contraindication for breastfeeding. While the other infections can be transmitted through breast milk, there are ways to reduce the risk of transmission and breastfeeding may still be an option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. HIV can be transmitted through breast milk, so it is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding. Hepatitis B and C can be transferred through breast milk, but can be prevented with proper screening and precautions. Latent tuberculosis does not pose a risk to the infant through breastfeeding, but active tuberculosis does.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, HIV is the only infection that is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding. Breastfeeding can transmit the virus to the infant, and formula feeding is recommended for HIV-positive mothers. Hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through breastfeeding, but antiviral therapy and protective measures can reduce the risk. Latent tuberculosis does not pose a risk to the infant during breastfeeding.
